repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Agricultural Development and Rural
            Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Development Project
            Performance Assessment Ratings (PPAR) are the same as the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings.  The Rural
            Development PPAR  differ from the ICR ; the outcome is rated
            as satisfactory; the institutional development impact is
            rated as substantial and overall Bank and Borrower
            performance performance is rated as satisfactory.  The
            lessons learned include the following:  (1) The success of a
            line of credit project is dependent not only upon its design
            but also on the institutional environment and human resource
            capacity of the country; (2) It is important to pay close
            attention to the incentive structures that are built into
            financial instruments like lines of credit, since these can
            represent the major difference between success and failure;
            and When a government creates a new financial instrument
            such as publicly provided credit to enhance the efficient
            functioning of private markets, it is important to have an
            exit strategy to move this instrument to the private sector.

5130498.trustfund:
TF029689-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEV. II PROJECT,TF024256-BALTIC-RIGA REGIONAL MISSION,TF039182-LATVIA - RURAL DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT - LATVIAN NATIONAL LANDBOOK

repnme.cdata!:
Diverse economic activities help fight
            rural poverty

abstracts.cdata!:
In 1997 the aggregate gross domestic
            product (GDP) share of agriculture, hunting, and forestry
            dropped to 7 percent, yet the proportion of those employed
            in this sector persisted at almost the same level, and more
            than a half of all people residing in the countryside were
            engaged in agriculture. In order to reduce poverty and
            unemployment, and to support the development of rural
            economy and expansion of alternative income earning
            opportunities, the World Bank and the Government of Latvia
            launched the rural development project late 1998. Under the
            agriculture development project only commercial credits were
            issued, while the goal of the second project is to give
            assistance also to those who need special support to access
            commercial credits for the first time. Alongside with the
            credit line, financing under the rural development project
            was assigned also to drafting the rural development policy
            and has been used in building a national integrated
            computerized land register. In 1997 54 percent of all
            economically active in the countryside were engaged in
            farming, but in 2000 - only 37 percent. Greater efficiency
            of economic activities in the rural areas shall be ensured
            through new forms of employment, and the question is what
            financial resources should support the attainment of it.

23978678.trustfund:
TF024256-BALTIC-RIGA REGIONAL MISSION,TF029689-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEV. II PROJECT,TF039182-LATVIA - RURAL DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT - LATVIAN NATIONAL LANDBOOK

abstracts.cdata!:
In the absence of any private sector
            interest, the agricultural finance company (AFC) was set up
            in 1993 with support from the World Bank. In its first five
            years, with just 42 staff, it approved some 2,860 loans for
            a total of 43 million dollars. Repayment performance was
            high, and it remains at over 90 percent. The AFC helped
            establish a rural financial system based on commercial
            lending terms, and conditions that were later adopted by
            commercial banks.

23827183.trustfund:
TF024256-BALTIC-RIGA REGIONAL MISSION,TF029689-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEV. II PROJECT,TF039182-LATVIA - RURAL DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT - LATVIAN NATIONAL LANDBOOK

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are high. Lessons learned suggest that
            for successful rural finance, four key elements play a
            significant role: legally based property ownership;
            functional legal systems; functional financial institutions;
            and, a system of effective farm advisory and business
            development support. To this end, prerequisites, such as the
            development of a property registration system, land markets,
            collateral registration, and mortgages, should be
            synchronized for the development of physical assets, and
            financial markets. However, in the provision of financial
            subsidies to the rural sector - through innovative hybrid
            grant-loans - such loans should be restricted to first-time
            borrowers only, with the understanding that the subsidy is a
            one-time catalyst, and not a recurring government handout.
            Additionally, tying the grant to a bank loan, conditions
            sub-borrowers to the discipline of loan payments, allowing
            the establishment of a credit history. Similarly, grant-loan
            credit lines for small loans, can effectively promote the
            establishment of new businesses in rural areas, thereby
            diversifying the rural economic base.

442737.trustfund:
TF024256-BALTIC-RIGA REGIONAL MISSION,TF039182-LATVIA - RURAL DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT - LATVIAN NATIONAL LANDBOOK,TF029689-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEV. II PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the first
            phase of the Rural Development Project is to lay the
            groundwork for increasing income levels and improving living
            standards of the rural population by promoting
            diversification and growth of economic activities in the
            rural areas. This would be done through: (a) strengthening
            policy formulation capacity for rural development strategies
            at national, regional, and local levels of government; (b)
            introducing participatory approaches to rural development to
            increase stakeholders' ownership and commitment; (c)
            providing credit and technical assistance to generate
            employment and income earning opportunities in rural areas;
            (d) further strengthening rural banking practices and rural
            business development service network consistent with
            principles applied in the EU; and (e) expanding support for
            the development of the emerging land market and legal
            registration system of private land and real estate. The
            rural development policy component includes development of
            rural development strategy and policies and implementation
            of rural development at local levels and animation of rural
            population to develop small scale business opportunities.
            The rural finance component includes commercial credit and
            special support for small scale rural entrepreneurs. The
            third component is institutional development.
